name: hard coal, import from ZA | hard coal | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/18637/documentation

This dataset describes the transport needed for the export of South African hard coal to India. Average coal losses and related emissions during transport and storage are included. These are based on generic estimates as no geography-specific data were available. The coal is transported from the mines by train to the coal export terminal in Richards Bay (RBCT) on the East Coast of South Africa. RBCT accounts for the handling of 95% of South Africa's export coal. Average distances of 550 km and 9,250 km are estimated for train and transoceanic freight transport, respectively. ;Around 30% of South Africa’s annual coal production is exported, with 31.9 million tonnes of hard coal exported to India in 2014 (accounting for 41% of total coal exports in 2014). Exports to India are of South Africa's lower grades of export coal and, as such, are supplied predominantly by lower grade washed coal products (particularly the middlings product) and to a lessor degree, higher grade unwashed coal (unwashed coal estimated to supply 5% of the exports to Indial). Exports to India are predominantly of the RB3 and RB2 (5,700) export grades, with calorific values in the range of 22 - 25 MJ/kg (LHV 5,500 kCal/kg), ash contents of up to 23% and volatile matter around 22%. South African coals are naturally low in sulphur (<1%).

Starting at the gate of the hard coal mine, this dataset includes the transport, re-loading and storage within the exporting country and transoceanic freight shipping.

This activity ends at the border of the importing country. The average transport within the importing country is not included in this dataset, it is covered in the respective market for hard coal.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The trade volumes represented in this dataset are based on 2014 Trademap export statistics retrieved online from www.trademap.org
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: South African values: not applicable worldwide
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The coal is transported from the mines by train to the Richards Bay coal export terminal on the East coast of South Africa. An average rail transport distance of 550 km is derived from a weighted average of the production volumes by coalfield and the distance from the respective coalfields to the Richards Bay Coal Terminal. A distance of 9,250 km transoceanic freight transport is estimated as the average distance along freight shipping routes between Richards Bay and the major ports importing coal in India.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Trade volumes are based on export data for 2014 according to the International Trade Centre (ITC) and South Africa's Department of Minerals and Resources (DMR). 95% of South Africa's export coal is exported through the Richards Bay coal terminal on the East Coast of South Africa. The distance that the coal is railed to the port for export is calculated from a weighted average of the average distance from the respective coalfields producing coal for export and the production volumes of export grade coal from each coalfield. The distances were estimated using Google Maps, while the production volumes were sourced from industry data. The average coal losses were assumed to be due wholly to particulate emissions during transport and storage of coal were estimated according to Chadwick et al., (1987) and NPI (2012). Due to a lack of site specific information, emissions to ground water (arising from leachate from coal stockpiles) have not been updated and use the same generic estimates as the other ecoivent coal mining datasets (i.e. they are  estimated with high uncertainty according to Dones et al. (2007), based on three studies conducted in the 1980s by Kok et al. (1989), ORNL (1980) and Zahner (1980)).  Conveyor belt usage was calculated on the basis of publically available data reported by the Richards Bay Coal Terminal (RBCT, 2014). 
Reference(s): Chadwick, M. J., Highton, N.H. and Lindman, N. (1987) Environmental Impacts of Coal Mining and Utilization: A Complete Revision of Environmental Implications of Expanded Coal Utilization; NPI (2012) Emission Estimation Technique Manual for Mining. Version 3.1, National Pollution Inventory, Available at: http://www.npi.gov.au/system/files/resources/7e04163a-12ba-6864-d19a-f57d960aae58/files/mining.pdf. (Accessed on: July 2017); Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No. 6-VI, Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH; Kok A., Bolt N., Jelgersma R. (1989) Spontaneous heating and stockpiling losses of coal. In: Kema Scientific & Technical Reports 7 (2):63-89; ORNL (1980) A Methodology and a Preliminary Data Base for Examining the Health Risks of Electricity Generation from Uranium and Coal Fuels. Oak Ridge, USA; Zahner Ph. (1985) Le stockage du charbon et du coke en plein air: pollution et protection des eaux. Les cahiers de l'environnement No 38, OFPE, Bern;  ITC (2017) Trademap Database, Available at: http://www.trademap.org/. (Accessed July 2017); DMR (2015) Operating and Developing Coal Mines in the Republic of South Africa 2015, Department of Mineral Resources. Available at: http://www.dmr.gov.za/. (Accessed: June 2017); RBCT (2014) Company Website, Richards Bay Coal Terminal. Available at: https://www.rbct.co.za/faq-6/. (Accessed July 2017).

flow.name: hard coal
flow.category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

exchanges.description:
Estimated value not geography specific (generic value used in other ecoinvent coal market datasets). This represents the leaching of Nickel to ground water during storage in open stockpiles. For a lack of more recent data this value is an estimation according to Dones et al. (2007) based on three studies conducted in the 1980s by Kok et al. (1989), ORNL (1980) and Zahner (1980). 500 liters of leachate per m2 of storage area are assumed for an average storage time of two months, an average pile height of 6m and a bulk density of 700kg/m3. High uncertainty for estimates of leachate emissions has to be assumed.
Reference(s): Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No. 6-VI, Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Kok A., Bolt N., Jelgersma R. (1989) Spontaneous heating and stockpiling losses of coal. In: Kema Scientific & Technical Reports 7 (2):63-89.
ORNL (1980) A Methodology and a Preliminary Data Base for Examining the Health Risks of Electricity Generation from Uranium and Coal Fuels. Oak Ridge, USA.
Zahner Ph. (1985) Le stockage du charbon et du coke en plein air: pollution et protection des eaux. Les cahiers de l'environnement No 38, OFPE, Bern.

exchanges.description:
Estimated value not geography specific (generic value used in other ecoinvent coal market datasets). This represents the TOC due to leaching to ground water during storage in open stockpiles. For a lack of more recent data this value is "Calculated by default as TOC (gC) = COD/2.7 (COD measured in g O2). Should more correctly be calculated from the carbon content of the specified emissions to water." according to Dones et al. (2007). 500 liters of leachate per m2 of storage area are assumed for an average storage time of two months, an average pile height of 6m and a bulk density of 700kg/m3. High uncertainty for estimates of leachate emissions has to be assumed.
Reference(s): Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen
von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von
Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die
Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No. 6-VI, Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen, Swiss Centre
for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.

This is the weighted average transport distance from the four major coal fields producing export grade coal i.e. Witbank (82.4%), Highveld (9.1%), Ermelo (8.4%) and Waterberg (0.1%) to the primary coal exporting port, Richards Bay Coal Terminal (RBCT). 

Source: The distances were estimated using Google Maps, while the breakdown of export coal by coalfield was determined from industry data (SACRM, 2011).

Estimated value not geography specific (generic value used in other ecoinvent coal market datasets). This represents the BOD caused by leaching to ground water during storage in open stockpiles. For a lack of more recent data this value is an estimation according to Dones et al. (2007) based on three studies conducted in the 1980ies by Kok et al. (1989), ORNL (1980) and Zahner (1980). 500 liters of leachate per m2 of storage area are assumed for an average storage time of two months, an average pile height of 6m and a bulk density of 700kg/m3. High uncertainty for estimates of leachate emissions has to be assumed.
Reference(s): Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen
von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von
Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die
Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No. 6-VI, Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen, Swiss Centre
for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Kok A., Bolt N., Jelgersma R. (1989) Spontaneous heating and stockpiling losses of
coal. In: Kema Scientific & Technical Reports 7 (2):63-89.
ORNL (1980) A Methodology and a Preliminary Data Base for Examining the Health
Risks of Electricity Generation from Uranium and Coal Fuels. Oak Ridge, USA.
Zahner Ph. (1985) Le stockage du charbon et du coke en plein air: pollution et
protection des eaux. Les cahiers de l'environnement No 38, OFPE, Bern.

Coal exports to India are medium grade and low grade (RB2(5700) and RB3), with CV of 22-25 MJ/kg and ash content 17-23%. As such this market is supplied predominantly by lower grade washed coal products (particularly the middlings product) and to a lessor degree higher grade unwashed coal (estimated at 5% of the supply to Indial).  Product losses are assumed to arise only from particulate emissions. Due to a lack of site specific data, this value is based on emission factors for loading, unloading, transit and stockpiling stages. Up to 14% of coal arriving at the export terminal is loaded directly onto waiting ships, thus emissions associated with stockpiling 14% of the coal was exluded. Losses on the Indian side taken from the Indian CERC (Central Electricity regulatory Commision) guidelines which gives a loss of 0.8 % as transit and handling loss for non pit-head power plants.Source: Emission factors for loading, unloading and transit via rail and ship from Chadwick, M. J., Highton, N.H. and Lindman, N. (1987) Environmental Impacts of Coal Mining and Utilization: A Complete Revision of Environmental Implications of Expanded Coal Utilization.   Emissions factors for loading/unloading of stockpile and during stockpiling due to wind erosion from NPI (2012) Emission Estimation Technique Manual for Mining. Version 3.1, National Pollution Inventory, Available at: http://www.npi.gov.au/system/files/resources/7e04163a-12ba-6864-d19a-f57d960aae58/files/mining.pdf. (Accessed on: July 2017). Percentage of coal loaded directly onto ships from RBCT (2014) Company Website: Infrastructure, Richards Bay Coal Terminal. Available at: https://www.rbct.co.za/operations-6/infrastructure/. (Accessed July 2017).

exchanges.description:
This is an estimate of the average distance for sea transport of hard coal exports from South Africa's primary coal export terminal (RBCT) to major Indian coal importing ports (East India are Paradip, Haldia, Gangavaram and Chennai while in West India are Mundra, GOA, Cochin and Dahej). 

Sources: Major ports online from opensea.pro, 2017, <https://opensea.pro/blog/shipping-coal>, accessed July 2017; distance approximated based on Ports.com <http://ports.com/sea-route/>.

exchanges.description:
Estimated value not geography specific (generic value used in other ecoinvent coal market datasets). This represents the leaching of Lead to ground water during storage in open stockpiles. For a lack of more recent data this value is an estimation according to Dones et al. (2007) based on three studies conducted in the 1980s by Kok et al. (1989), ORNL (1980) and Zahner (1980). 500 liters of leachate per m2 of storage area are assumed for an average storage time of two months, an average pile height of 6m and a bulk density of 700kg/m3. High uncertainty for estimates of leachate emissions has to be assumed.

Reference(s): Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No. 6-VI, Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Kok A., Bolt N., Jelgersma R. (1989) Spontaneous heating and stockpiling losses of coal. In: Kema Scientific & Technical Reports 7 (2):63-89.
ORNL (1980) A Methodology and a Preliminary Data Base for Examining the Health Risks of Electricity Generation from Uranium and Coal Fuels. Oak Ridge, USA.
Zahner Ph. (1985) Le stockage du charbon et du coke en plein air: pollution et protection des eaux. Les cahiers de l'environnement No 38, OFPE, Bern.

Estimated value not geography specific (generic value used in other ecoinvent coal market datasets).  This represents the leaching of inorganic solids to ground water during storage in open stockpiles. For a lack of more recent data this value is an estimation according to Dones et al. (2007) based on three studies conducted in the 1980ies by Kok et al. (1989), ORNL (1980) and Zahner (1980). 500 liters of leachate per m2 of storage area are assumed for an average storage time of two months, an average pile height of 6m and a bulk density of 700kg/m3. High uncertainty for estimates of leachate emissions has to be assumed.
Reference(s): Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen
von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von
Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die
Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No. 6-VI, Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen, Swiss Centre
for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Kok A., Bolt N., Jelgersma R. (1989) Spontaneous heating and stockpiling losses of
coal. In: Kema Scientific & Technical Reports 7 (2):63-89.
ORNL (1980) A Methodology and a Preliminary Data Base for Examining the Health
Risks of Electricity Generation from Uranium and Coal Fuels. Oak Ridge, USA.
Zahner Ph. (1985) Le stockage du charbon et du coke en plein air: pollution et
protection des eaux. Les cahiers de l'environnement No 38, OFPE, Bern.

Conveyor belt use associated with coal handling estimated from that of the Richards Bay Coal Terminal. As at 2014, RBCT reported the use of 56km belting and structures with a capacity of 90 million tonnes coal per year. Exports to India account for 41% of total coal exports from SA. 

Source: RBCT (2014) Company Website, Richards Bay Coal Terminal. Available at: https://www.rbct.co.za/faq-6/. (Accessed July 2017).

flow.name: transport, freight, conveyor belt
flow.category: H:Transportation and storage/49:Land transport and transport via pipelines/492:Other land transport

exchanges.description:
Due to a lack of site specific data, this value is based on emission factors for loading, unloading, transit and stockpiling stages. Up to 14% of coal arriving at the export terminal is loaded directly onto waiting ships, thus emissions associated with stockpiling 14% of the coal was exluded. Losses on the Indian side taken from the Indian CERC (Central Electricity regulatory Commision) guidelines which gives a loss of 0.8 % as transit and handling loss for non pit-head power plants (personal communication), 

Sources: 
Emission factors for loading, unloading and transit via rail and ship from Chadwick, M. J., Highton, N.H. and Lindman, N. (1987) Environmental Impacts of Coal Mining and Utilization: A Complete Revision of Environmental Implications of Expanded Coal Utilization;   Emissions factors for loading/unloading of stockpile and during stockpiling due to wind erosion from NPI (2012) Emission Estimation Technique Manual for Mining. Version 3.1, National Pollution Inventory, Available at: http://www.npi.gov.au/system/files/resources/7e04163a-12ba-6864-d19a-f57d960aae58/files/mining.pdf. (Accessed on: July 2017).;
Percentage of coal loaded directly onto ships from RBCT (2014) Company Website: Infrastructure, Richards Bay Coal Terminal. Available at: https://www.rbct.co.za/operations-6/infrastructure/. (Accessed July 2017).
